Award.AwardTitle: IRES: U.S. - Belgium Bioengineering Collaboration with International Research Experience for Students
Award.AbstractNarration:
Johns Hopkins University (JHU) will team with the Belgian Interuniversity Micro-Electronics Centre (IMEC) to provide a three-year program of international research experience for U.S. undergraduate and graduate students through projects at the interface of nanoscience and medical science. During ten-week internships abroad, students will work on cooperative research projects, mentored by JHU researchers and counterparts at IMEC. Prior to their internships in Belgium, student participants will prepare by spending the academic year working with a research group at Johns Hopkins University or in a laboratory where they can develop essential technical skills that are relevant to an ongoing JHU-IMEC project. Through this well balanced, collaborative research program with intensive, early career student engagement, the principal investigator and his Belgian counterparts intend to pursue results that lead to bioengineering advances in therapeutic polymer-nanoparticle drug delivery and medical diagnostics, with the long-term goal of improving future healthcare technologies.

The US-Belgian International Research Experience for Students (IRES) focuses on bioengineering and combines the complementary strengths of JHU in biomedical sciences and complementary IMEC expertise in nanotechnology and microfabrication. As the international partner, IMEC offers: (1) state-of-the-art microfabrication facilities and staffing, (2) a well-established life sciences research group dedicated to finding ways to apply nano-electronics to healthcare, and (3) a diverse, international and multicultural R&D environment. The U.S. students, recruited from diverse backgrounds, who are involved in this program will be exposed to teamwork in the global economy and will be trained in a research field that has significant potential societal impact.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Research Experience for Students (IRES) program, housed within Johns Hopkins University’s Institute for NanoBioTechnology, provided summer research training for 5 students in summer of 2019. The program attracted an application pool of 14 diverse students. The cohort included 40% underrepresented monitories and 60% women.

This IRES program has achieved its overall goal of engaging students through hands-on research experiences, following best practices for retaining students from diverse backgrounds, and providing unique experiences in micro-electronics research. The program has also laid the foundation for interest in graduate research, future student presentations, and published papers. After the IRES program, all of the students completed our survey, in which 80% reported an increase in their confidence in their ability to do research. Over 80% of the interns stated that the IRES program broadened their research skills. All interns reported feeling like an integral part of a research team, while at IMEC. All interns also agreed that they would recommend the IRES program to others. The interns recounted that the most valuable aspects of the experience were their mentors, learning to work independently, and meeting students and researchers from different parts of the world

New discoveries in the biomedical sciences are enabling technology solutions with the potential to shape the future of healthcare.  Numerous companies and start-ups are developing technologies that enable detection of biomarkers at the level of single molecules and single cells with massive parallelization. The adaptation of silicon chip manufacturing is key to enabling these technologies and allowing these new products to become reality.  This IRES program focuses on the development of microelectronics-based platform technologies for biosensors, PCR-on-a-chip, high throughput cell sorting and FACS, microfluidics, microelectronic arrays, neural probes, smart implantable devices, biophotonics, and imaging and spectroscopy.  Together JHU and IMEC have complementary expertise and are well positioned to create new science and technologies at the intersection of microelectronics and the biomedical sciences. The students participated in responsible conduct of research training and were fully immersed in lab research and projects with intellectual merit.  Projects during the summer of 2019 include:

  • UV curable resins for microfluidics
  • Single cell electroporation and lysis
  • Heart-on-chip: development of in vitro cardiotoxicity assays
  • Integrated microscale DNA capture and quantification
  • High resolution on-chip fluorescence imaging using photonic ICs

 

This IRES internship provided these students with an opportunity to perform research abroad in a state-of-the-art facility. It also provided them the opportunity to work with scientists and engineers from other backgrounds and cultures, enabled a perspective on the global economy, and hence contributed to training the next generation of U.S. technology innovators and leaders. Whilst at IMEC, IRES students had numerous opportunities to network and develop their communication skills.  In addition, through their blog posts, students will gained a better understanding of how to communicate their research to a non-technical audience and the value of social media as a tool to educate.

Alumni from the 2019 cohort have gone on to be awarded the Intramural Research Training Award. One student has been accepted to Master of Engineering program at Johns Hopkins, another is working in industry, and another plans to complete his PhD in 2021.

Overall, the IRES program, has attracted, trained, and mentored a diverse and talented group of students.
